loans.use: Purchase goods for his store

loans.name: Elchin

texts.ru:
Elchin K. 42 qoda . On jenat i otec 5 detey. Starshaya doch kotoroy 18 let v etom qodu postupila v universitet, Dochka 16 let uchitsya v shkole na otlichniccu, Sin sin 14 let uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya futbollom, dochka 13 let toje uchitsya v shkole, i dochka 10 let toje uchitsya v shkole a tak je xodit na tanci nacionalniye.

Elchin uje 10 let kak v etom biznese. Etomu biznessu yeqo nauchil yeqo otec kotoriy toje bil masnikom. Elchin seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit skot dlya prodaji.
texts.en:
Elchin K. is 42 years old. He is married with five children. His eldest daughter who is 18 years old has enrolled this year at the university. His 16-year-old daughter studies in school with excellence. His 14-year-old son is a student and plays soccer. His 13-year-old daughter is also in school. His 10-year-old daughter is also a student and also goes to folk dancing. Elchin has been in this business for 10 years. He learned this line of work from his father who was also a butcher. Elchin now needs 2000 AZN in order to buy livestock for sale.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy livestock for resale

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 46 years old and is married with seven children. He runs Jako Motors and it’s thirteen years since he started the business which has ten employees.

Richard appreciates Faulu Kenya because he has managed to obtain financial support which he used to buy business assets. He has requested a loan of 30,000 KES to buy a spraying machine.

Richard hopes to expand his business to other locations. He describes himself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy a spraying machine

loans.name: Rita's Group

texts.en: Rita K. is the leader of this group. She is 34 and married with a son and a daughter, both of whom are at school. Four years ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 soms Rita and her husband began to sell fruits and vegetables in the market and in this way they make 3,000 soms per month. With the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of fruits and vegetables (potatoes – 40kg, cucumbers – 40kg, carrots – 25kg, etc.) in order to sell them in the market. In the future Rita wants to expand her business and then start building a big new house. Nagiripa C. is the treasurer of the group. She is 57 and a widow and has raised two sons and four daughters. Most of them are married and live separately with their families. Nagiripa started repairing her house and hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase building materials. Kanybek U. U. is 20. A year ago, with an initial investment of 2,000 soms, he started to breed livestock. He sells eggs and resells livestock after fattening and in this way he makes 3,000 soms per month. With the loan, he wants to purchase five farm animals in order to sell them at a higher price after fattening. In the future he wants to save money to build a house. Aidai C., 36, is divorced and has two daughters, both of whom are at school. Five years ago, with an initial investment of 3,000 soms, she started to sell fruits and vegetables and in this way she makes 5,000 soms per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more fruits and vegetables in order to increase the turnover of her business. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 42 years old and is widowed with three children. She has been running a greengrocer shop for fifteen years and also farms to supplement her family’s income. She says that as a mother and the sole breadwinner in her family, she strives to raise her children.

Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, Susan’s living standard has improved. She has requested 30,000 KES to buy a heifer (a young female cow that has not borne a calf). She hopes to increase her business stock in the future. She also dreams of expanding her farming to a larger scale.

loans.use: To buy a heifer

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis K. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, all of whom are currently in school. Francis has a bar business which he has had for less than one year. He also sells fish.

To help expand his business, Francis has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda which will be used to purchase more creates of soda and beers. With the help of this loan, he hopes to generate greater profits and be able to pay his children’s school fees.

In the future, Francis hopes to educate his children up to university level.

loans.use: To buy more creates of soda and beer

loans.name: Anjao

texts.en:
Anjao is a 33-year-old business-lady who runs A.’s Grocery. She is the mother of two children who are in school.

Anjao sells oranges, pawpaw, onions, bananas and tomatoes in her grocery shop and has been in the business for two years. She has been an active member of Embakasi Trust group in Faulu Kenya and says that since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to manage her finances and loans.

Anjao has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy a blender, crates of eggs and polythene bags for packaging her products. She hopes to open a wholesale business in the future.

loans.use: To buy a blender, crates of eggs and polythene bags for packaging her products

loans.name: Surayo

texts.ru: Халимова Сураё проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 40 лет. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей на рынке. Она продает материалы для штор. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 4 года. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Surayo H. lives in the town of Kurgan-Tiube. She is 40 years old, married and has two children. She completed high school. She is engaged in trade at the market. She sells materials for sewing. She has been involved in this line of business for four years. The loan enables her to expand her assortment of goods.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the assortment

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is married and has a two-year-old child.  He is a humble and God-fearing farmer.  He does mixed farming to earn a living.  He sells farm produce such as milk, potatoes and kale (sukuma wiki).  Samuel has been running his business for eight years and has been able to save his money through Faulu Kenya.  He has requested 30,000 KES to buy a cow and animal feed.  He dreams of becoming a prosperous businessman.  He sees himself becoming a large scale farmer in the future.

loans.use: To buy a cow and animal feeds

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn A. is a married woman who lives in Purok Paho, Barangay Pacol, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living through vegetable vending, growing and selling rice, and dressmaking businesses. Her husband, Manuel A. Sr., who is 45 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 18 and 19 years old. 

Jocelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seventeen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jocelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of approximately $230, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 18th cycle loan, she is borrowing 25,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy fertilizers, pesticides and insecticides for the farm so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Jocelyn A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: Magdalena's Group

texts.en:
Magdalena A. is from the village of Arcon. She is 52 years old and the group leader of a nine member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Magdalena A..

She is married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $115 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Magdalena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Magdalena is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 5th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ssulaiman

texts.en:
Sulaiman J. is 36 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, all of whom are currently in school. He has a business of selling clothes, which he has had for less than one year.         

To help expand his business, Sulaiman has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes to sell.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, he hopes to generate greater profits and improve on the family's standard of living. In the future, Sulaiman hopes to own a shop with his wife.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Zaynura

texts.ru: Шарипова Зайнура проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 32 года. Разведена, имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее. Более 8 лет занимается торговлей на центральном рынке города. Арендует торговую точку, где продает женское нижнее белье. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Zainura S. lives in the city of Kurgan-Tiube. She is 32 years old, divorced and has two children. She completed high school. For more than eight years, she has been engaged in trade in the central city market. She runs a trade stall, where she sells women's underwear. The loan will allow her to expand her assortment of goods.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her variety of goods

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B. is a 41-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating both a general store and a livestock business. She lives in Purok 1, Barangay Mantuyop, Siaton, Negros Oriental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $210. 

Evelyn is now borrowing 15,000 PHP so that she can continue purchasing items like vitamins and other supplies to sell. This will be her 4th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Evelyn hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory to sell

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a 40-year-old member of the Embakasi Upendo group in Faulu Kenya.  She is married and has three children aged 10, 5 and 2.  All her children are in school.  

For a living, she sells second-hand clothes. She has been running the business for two years.  Previously she was operating a grocery shop to earn a living.  Through Faulu Kenya, she has been encouraged to save her money.  

Violet has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to increase her stock of clothes.  She hopes to open a boutique in the future.  In five years, she wants to diversify into other products.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothes

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita joined ASHI in 2007, a KIVA partner in the Philippines. When she received her previous loans from Kiva, she invested the money in her business and later expanded the business by ordering a stock of ingredients to put into production. 

Now on her 4th loan, she has requested 16,000 PHP as additional working capital for her business ventures. She is positive that her business will grow since she already has regular customers requesting orders at home. Tita is still hopeful that by growing her business of making and selling “bandi” (a sweet peanut delicacy) her profit will increase as well. Then she would be able to support her children’s education and hopefully will have a better career in the future.

“Bandi” is one of the most popular delicacies of Antique province and tourists buy it as a present. Demand for this product is increasing as the province industrializes. Tita wants to have a large amount of capital to increase her production, thus meeting the demands of her customers.

She dreams of having a permanent space in the marketplace where she can sell her “bandi” to earn a much larger income. She hopes to have success in a business that can provide her a good life that is moved out of poverty. Tita is grateful to ASHI for offering her happiness in life and group support in achieving her goals.

loans.use: additional working capital for her making and selling "bandi" (a sweet peanut delicacy)

loans.name: Madina

texts.ru: Холова Мадина проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 23 года. Не замужем. Образование среднее. Живет вместе с родителями. Занимается торговлей. Арендует магазин на центральном рынке района. Она в основном продает мужскую и женскую одежду. В этой области имеет хороший опыт. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Madina K. lives in the Vakhdat region. She is 23 years old, unmarried and has completed high school. She lives with her parents. She is engaged with trade. She runs a store in the central market of the region. She generally sells men's and women's clothing. She has good experience in this area. The loan brings the opportunity to expand inventory.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Nieta Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Nieta, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font la restauration et le commerce des habillements.Ces femmes du groupe Nieta sont à leur huitième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des habillements, des céréales et des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration.  
FANTA O. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des habillements pour toutes catégories de personnes.                                                                                                        Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises le plus généralement à Bamako et au Burkina Faso et effectue sa vente à la maison et en ambulance, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50 000F CFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Nieta group are all married with four children, around 41 years old and live in large extended families in the village of Marka-Counga in the municipality of Fana, the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through friends and family and are involved in foodsales and selling clothes, cereal and condiments. Fanta O. aims to use her loan in order to purchase clothes for a variety of people. She sources her goods from Bamako and Burkina Faso and sells them from her home or through door-to-door sales through cash and credit sales to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA which will be used to meet her family's needs and to invest in her business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouman, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 42 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font la restauration, le commerce d’habits, du lait et d’articles divers.                                                                                                              
Ces femmes du groupe Sabougnouman sont à leur huitième prêt solidaire. MARIAM MOUSSA C. du groupe Sabougnouman compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter beaucoup d’articles divers.
Elle s’approvisionne généralement avec les grossistes de la ville et à Bamako, elle effectue sa vente sur place à la maison au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Sabougnouman group are all married with three children, are around 42 years old and live in large extended families in the village of Marka-Coungo in the municipality of Fana, the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through friends and family, and are involved in foodsales and selling clothes, milk and other items. These women are on their 8th loan. Mariam Moussa C., a member of the group, aims to use her loan in order to purchase several items. She generally sources her goods from the wholesalers in her town and from Bamako, and she sells her goods from her home for cash or credit to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA which will be used to meet her family's needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Mahina

texts.ru: Каримова Махина проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 25 лет. Не замужем. Живет вместе с родителями. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей на рынке. У нее собственный продуктовый магазин. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Mahina K. lives in the Vakhdat region. She is 25 years old, unmarried and lives with her parents. She has a secondary education. She works in trade at the market. She has her own product store. She has been engaged in this type of activity for three years. The loan brings an opportunity to expand inventory.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 45 years old. She is married to Mr. Anaclito, who works as a driver, and they have one daughter, Joan, a 10-year-old grade school student. 

She joined ASHI because she wanted to have her own business, since her husband's income is not enough to sustain the daily needs of their family. She will use her loan of 10,000 PHP in her buying and selling of different small goods. Specifically, the loan fund will be used to pay for inventories of goods to sell. 

She and her husband aim to use KIVA loans to develop a stable business so they can support the education of their only daughter and have their own beautiful home.

loans.use: to pay for inventories of goods to sell

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkan, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 31  ans,  4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce, d’habits, de lait et du haricot. Elles sont  quatrième prêt solidaire.                                                                                                                                                                                  
BATA D. du groupe Benkan compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des habillements pour homme et femme et de tous âges.
Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises le plus généralement à Bamako avec les grossistes du marché et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Marka-coungo, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkan group are all married with four children, are 31 years old and live in large traditional families in the village of Marka-Counga, in the municipality of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through friends and family and sell clothes, milk and beans. They are on their fourth loan. Bata D. is a group member and aims to use the loan in order to buy clothes for men and women of all ages. She sources her goods from Bamako through wholesalers and sells her wares at the Marka-Coungo market for cash or credit to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA which will be used to see to her family's everyday needs and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothes

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans,  3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font la restauration, le commerce de tubercules et de beurre de karité. Ces femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur septième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour faire de la restauration, acheter des tubercules et du beurre de karité.                                                                                                                                                                                             
ASSETOU D. du groupe Djekafo compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des condiments alimentaires et du riz destinés à la restauration.
Elle s’approvisionne généralement avec les grossistes du marché de Bamako et quelques rare fois au marché de Marka-coungo, elle effectue la restauration au marché de Marka-coungo, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djekafo group are all 41 years old, married with three children, and live in large traditional families in the village of Marka-Coungo, in the municipality of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through friends and family and sell food, tubers and shea butter for a living. These women are on their seventh microfinance loan which will be used to purchase food, tubers and shea butter. Assetou Diarar, a member of the Djekafo group, aims to use her loan to purchase condiments and rice for the group's restaurant business. She generally sources her goods from wholesalers in the Bamako market and on occasions from the Marka-Coungo market; she then sells food from the Marka-Coungo market for cash or credit sales to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA, some of which will be used to see to her family's needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing condiments and rice

loans.name: Lolly

texts.en:
Lolly is 41 years old and has three children. She lives with her family in the province of Antique in the Philippines. To supply additional income for her family, she is starting a tricycle transport business. A tricycle is a motorcycle with a sidecar attached used as a public utility vehicle.

Lolly would like to receive a loan to pay for the maintenance of the tricycle.  As a member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines, she is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.  
 
With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.  Her long term dreams are to continue supporting her children as well as building a stronger home that can withstand flooding, which is common in her province.

loans.use: To pay for the maintenance of her tricycle transport business

loans.name: Jolidenw Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées, les femmes du groupe Jolidenw, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce de produits cosmétique, de condiments, de fruits et de pâte d’arachide.                                                                                                             
Ces femmes du groupe Jolidenw sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire.                                                                                       
MATOUKOUNE K., compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des paquets de condiments alimentaires.
Elle s’approvisionne en condiments le plus généralement avec les grossistes de Bamako et au marché de Marka-coungo et effectue sa vente sur place et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Jolidenw group are all around 40 years old, married with three children, and live in large extended families in the village of Marka-Coungo, in the municipality of Fana, the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through friends and family and sell cosmetics, condiments, fruit and peanut butter for a living. The women are on their fifth microfinance loan. Matoukoune K., a member of the group, aims to use her loan in order to buy packets of condiments. She generally sources her goods from wholesalers at the Bamako and Marka-Coungo markets, and sells her wares from home or at the markets for cash or credit sales to a customer base composed of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA, some of which will be used to meet her family's needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing condiments

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more crushed rocks to sell

loans.name: Bahrullo

texts.ru: Нозимов Бахрулло проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 32 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Живет вместе с родителями. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Бахрулло имеет средне - специальное образование, шафер. По специальности проработал 6 лет. Сейчас он занимается торговлей. У него магазин, где он продает продуктовые товары. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 2 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Bahrullo N. lives in the Vakhdat region. He is 32 years old, married and has three children. He lives with his parents. His wife works at home. Bahrullo has specialized secondary education as a chauffeur. He worked in his specialty for six years, but now works in trade. He has a store where he sells products and goods. He has pursued these kinds of activities for two years. The loan brings the opportunity to expand his inventory.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand inventory

loans.name: Kibaroudouman Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kibaroudouman, ont en moyenne 31 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles sont toutes mariées, se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce, de chaussures, de bois de chauffe et de gâteaux.                                                                                                            
Ces femmes du groupe Kibaroudouman sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des chaussures, de la farine de blé et du bois de chauffe.                                                                                       
BATOMA D. du groupe Kibaroudouman compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des chaussures en plastique pour enfants et adultes.
Elle s’approvisionne le plus généralement à Bamako et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Marka-Coungo au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Kibaroudouman group are 31 years-old with 3 children each, and live in large traditional families in the Marka-Coungo village, municipality of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of Mali). They are all married and met through friends and family; they sell shoes, firewood and cakes for a living. These women are on their first microfinance loan and would use it to purchase shoes, flour and firewood. Batoma D., a member of the Kibaroudouman group, aims to use her loan to purchase plastic shoes for children and adults. She sources her goods from Bamako and sells them from the Marka-Coungo market for cash and credit sales to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which will be used to meet her family's everyday needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing shoes

loans.name: Juanita's Group

texts.en:
Juanita C., from the village of Mangandingay Cabarroguis, Quirino, is the 45-year-old group leader of a three-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Juanita, who is married and has two school-aged children, owns and operates a direct-selling business offering cosmetics and apparel products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Juanita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ignace

texts.en:
Ignace is 29 years and single. Ignace lives with his parents and he has to contribute to supporting his family. That's the reason why he works hard so as to provide whatever they need in his family. Apart from that, Ignace owns a business selling various products for his store. This store sells various products such as:  rice; cosmetic products; has computers for secretarial services and so on. Ignace’s business is known and organized. This is his 5th year of successful operation of his business. The hours of his business are from are from 7 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except Saturdays.

Ignace is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business which will make him more efficient. With this expansion, Ignace will be able to satisfy his customers who will allow him to earn more profits to be used in his business and in his family.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en: Florencia C. is from the village of Magsaysay Saguday Quirino. She is 35 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Florencia owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Florencia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Florencia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Florencia is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Florencia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Indyiboneye Group

texts.fr:
Beatha Mukakizima, née à Ruhuha l’Est du Rwanda, il a 37 ans, il est marié et il a 4 enfants, son ainé a 13 ans et son cadet a 2 ans, son niveau d’étude est primaire. Elle vit avec sa famille à Ruhuha Bugesera. Un seul enfant va à l’école.
Elle appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé INDYIBONEYE cultivateurs de riz,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  agriculteurs de riz et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Béate et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en payant les minervals pour leurs enfants. Le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les engrais chimique pour felitiliser leur champ. Quand le groupe récolte, une partie de la récolte est vendue et une autre est utilisée pour les familles.
texts.en:
Béate Mukakizima was born in Ruhuha, in eastern Rwanda. She is 37 years old, married and has 4 children. Her eldest is 13 years old and her youngest is 2 years old. She has completed primary school. She lives with her family in Ruhuha Bugesera. Only one of her children goes to school. She belongs to Indyiboneye, a solidarity group of rice growers who guarantee each other’s loans. Béate and her group work to support their families, to improve their quality of life and to pay their children’s tuition fees. The group has taken out a loan from Amasezerano Community Banking to buy chemical fertiliser for their fields. When the group harvests their crops, part of it is sold and the rest is saved for their families.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertiliser

loans.name: Gevorg

texts.en:
Gevorg N. is from the town of Artik in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Gevorg’s goal is to provide a university education for his seventeen year old daughter and nineteen year old son.  He would also like to fulfill his wife’s dream to renovate the family home.

To meet these goals, Gevorg would like to expand his furniture production business.  He has been in this business for eleven years, running the company since his father’s retirement.  Gevorg is looking to the favorable terms and service of microfinance to invest in his business.

He wants a loan to purchase additional raw materials for the furniture business.  According to his business plan, this investment will grow his family income by twenty percent.

Gevorg is a well respected business man in Artik and enjoys living close to his extended family and friends.  The proceeds from the investment will also help Gevorg to support his parents and his brother’s family.

loans.use: the purchase of raw material

loans.name: Makongo K.k. Group

texts.en:
Francisca M. is in her early thirties and is married with one child. She owns a second hand clothes shop and has been running it for one year. The shop is open daily between 8 am and 8 pm and earns Fransisca a good monthly profit. 

This will be Fransisca's first motisha loan with Tujijenge Tanzania.  A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. Fransisca aims to use this loan to buy used clothes at wholesale prices so that she can increase her stock. 

Fransisca will share this loan with her loan group Makongo K.K., which totals 8 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Francisca is in the back row, in the middle.

loans.use: Increase stock of used clothes.

loans.name: Madona Group

texts.en:
Ndigwaku T. is in her early thirties and is married with two children. For the past two years, she has been running her own broiler farming business. She works daily between 6:30 am and 6 pm and makes a good monthly profit.

This will be Ndigwaku's 2nd loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loan to increase her chicken population, a loan which she has successfully repaid. With this loan, Ndigwaku aims to buy more chick feed as well as medecine. 

Ndigwaku will share this loan with her loan group 'Madona', which totals 20 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the photo, Ndigwaku is the tallest person in the back, wearing a head scarf.

loans.use: chicken feed and chicken medicine

loans.name: Francois Xavier

texts.en:
Francois Xavier is 28 years and single. Francois Xavier takes care of dependent relatives. He owns a store which contains various products such as: cosmetic products; rice, sugar, etc. Francois Xavier has an experience of 3 years and the hours of his business are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the morning every day except on Saturday. Francois Xavier's business is well organised and known in his residence place.

Francois Xavier is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business through purchasing more products for his store. With this expansion; he expects to attract more customers which is the best way of earning more profits to be used in his family and in his business.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: C2139 Urumuri Group

texts.en: Rose is 54 years old and married with five children: the first one is 23 and the last one is 12. Rose also takes care of two dependents. Rose is a businesswoman – she owns a business selling soft drinks (such as milk and sodas) and cakes. Her hours of business are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day. Even though she has her own occupation, she is the leader of this group which contains five members. This group is called Urumuri in their language. Rose and her group members are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand their businesses. They expect they will be able to earn more profits because, with more products, they can satisfy more customers. This is the best way of earning more for each business person on the whole.

loans.use: To purchase more products for their business

loans.name: Jennifer Ichela

texts.en:
Jennifer Ichela R. is 50 years old and is married to Steven R. who is a farmer and who also contributes to the income of the family. They have five school-going children and live in Kapsoya.

Jennifer has been operating a general store for twelve years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 25,000.

Jennifer learned about KADET through marketing awareness done in her area and is applying for her first loan of Kshs 50,000. She intends to use the loan to buy six boxes of cooking oil, five bags of sugar and any other stock which needs to be added. With the anticipated profits, she plans to expand her shop business.

In the future, Jennifer wishes to have more dairy cows since both businesses have proved to be very profitable in her area. Her deeper desire is to see her children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy six boxes of cooking oil,  five bags of sugar and other stock

loans.name: Abahujumutima Shyara 10 Group

texts.fr:
Ndagijimana Claver, né à Ruhuha l’Est du Rwanda,un homme de 37 ans, il est marié et il a 4 enfants, son ainé a 13 ans et son cadet a 1 ans, son niveau d’étude est primaire.Il vit avec sa famille à Ruhuha Bugesera. 3 enfants vont à l’école.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé ABAHUJUMUTIMA SHYARA NO 10 cultivateurs de riz,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  agriculteurs de riz et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Claver et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en payant les minervals pour leurs enfants. Le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les engrais chimique pour felitiliser leur champ. Quand le groupe récolte, une partie de la récolte est vendue et une autre est utilisée pour les familles.
texts.en:
Ndagijimana Claver, born in Ruhuha, in the East of Rwanda, is married with four children, the oldest being 13 years old and the youngest 1 year old. He has finished primary school, and he lives with his family in Ruhuha Bugesera. Three of his children are in school. He belongs to a solidarity group of rice farmers called Abahujumutima Shyara No. 10. The group members all cultivate rice and guarantee each others' loans. Claver and his group work to support their families and improve their life conditions as well as to pay their childrens' school fees. The group has taken out a loan from Amasezerano Community Banking in order to purchase chemical fertilizers for their field. After the harvest, a part is sold and the other is used by the group members’ families.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizers (urea, nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium) and manual labor

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty Bwanika is a 46-year-old mother of four, and her computer services business has been in existence for the last 7 years in Prison zone-Mpigi. She mostly offers computer training and photocopying services. This business, she says, was begun with encouragement from her husband. Betty also owns poultry and rental enterprises. Profits from these two businesses help her cover her basic home expenses. By her own account, she makes 200,000 shillings in a week. With this loan, she wants to buy necessary computer materials that she will be using to improve her services.

loans.use: To purchase more computer materials

loans.name: Kakira Women's Group-Jinja

texts.en: 45 year old L. Grace belongs to Kakira Women’s group-Jinja. 10 years is the time this engaging and highly spirited mother of 6 has been striking a happy medium overseeing her food and local brew sells in Kakira.  To her, hard work has become a rooted inclination in the course of plying her business. Local brew sales was her first business but, with time, she started combining it with mushrooms and other food sales. Grace also ekes out additional profits through selling fish. Each week, her profits add up to 100,000 shillings and with the auspices of this loan she is anticipating purchasing more drums that, she says, will help in the easier brewing of her crude alcohol.

loans.use: The purchase of more drums for making alcohol.

loans.name: Faida Group

texts.fr: Kungwa Wilondja  M. T. est  secrétaire du groupe Faida, âgée de 48 ans, mariée, mère de 10 enfants, son mari est pasteur, serviteur de Dieu dans une communauté pentecôtiste 8e CEPAC dans la ville de Goma,  paroisse de Virunga. Son fils ainé a 26 ans et le cadet a 7 ans. ces 8 enfants  étudient, sauf  un enfant qui a une maladie chronique, un autre qui a pris un repos volontaire.  Il y a 3 ans  révolus qu’elle vend les patates douces. Elle a commence avec ses fonds propre reçu de son mari environ 20$.   Elle expose ses marchandises dans un point de vente, sur la rue, dans le quartier Kasika, avenue lualaba n01. Ce crédit va lui permettre d’augmenter  son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  200 kg de patates douces pour 40$, les restes vont servir pour payer les frais scolaires de ses enfants  et l’épargne  pour prévenir la chute. Parfois, elle connait des pourritures de patates suite aux mauvaises conservations. Elle souhaite changer l’activité et  acheter une machine  tricoteuse. Et pour sa famille, elle veut scolariser confortablement ses enfants. La cliente Kungwa Wilondja  M. T. remercie  Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres citoyens exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Faida  est composé de 23 membres et que les clientes Kahindo S. et Kahindo Luvatsungana sont absentes mais représentées respectivement  par leurs maris.
texts.en:
Kungwa Wilondja M. T. is the secretary to the Faida group. She is 48 years old, married and the mother of 10 children. Her husband is a minister, a servant of God in the Pentecostal community, 8th CEPAC (Pentacostal Community of Central Africa), in the city of Goma, Virunga parish. Her oldest son is 26 years old and the youngest is 7. Her 8 children are in school, except for one who has a chronic illness and another who has voluntarily taken time off. She has been selling sweet potatoes for 3 years. She started her business with around $20 provided by her husband. She displays her merchandise at a sales place on the street in the Kasika district, No. 1 Lualaba Avenue. This loan will enable her to buy 200 kg of sweet potatoes for $40 and increase her sales. The remainder of the loan will be used to pay for her children’s school expenses and to save for a rainy day. Sometimes she finds rotten potatoes as a result of poor preservation. She wants to change her business and buy a knitting machine. For her family, she wants to be able to easily send her children to school. Client Kungwa Wilondja M. T. thanks Hekima for its actions in favor of poor citizens excluded from traditional banks. It is noted that the Faida group is composed of 23 members and that clients Kahindo S. and Kahindo Luvatsungana are absent but represented by their respective husbands.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 200 kg of sweet potatoes for $40, the remainder to be used to pay for the school expenses of her children and savings

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Hannah Waruguru

texts.en:
Hannah Waruguru is 41 years old and is married to Peter K. who is a driver and so is a source of additional income for the family. They have three school-going children and they live in Mitero, Thika.

Hannah practices dairy farming and has been in this business for two years, earning a monthly profit of Kshs 10,000.

Hannah learned about KADET through marketing awareness done in her area. She is applying for her first loan of Kshs 25,000 which she intends to use to buy rabbits to enhance her income from dairy farming. This will be her secondary business. With the anticipated profits, she plans to expand her rabbit-keeping business.

In the future Hannah wishes to start poultry farming since this businesses has proved to be very profitable in her area. Her deeper desire is to see her children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy rabbits to raise in addition to her dairy farming

loans.name: Nsaggu Akugoba Women's Group-Mpigi

texts.en: Thirty-nine year old David K., who belongs to Nsaggu Akugoba Women’s group-Mpigi, has been in general merchandise retailing for the last 7 years. Self-motivation is what made him an upstart in this business, he is so endeared on the basis that he and his family have met financial from the business. David values his hard work and it’s the sole reason he says he has achieved this longevity. David is happily married with 4 kids. In a week, his business generates him shillings 100,000, and with this loan he is looking at purchasing more bags of sugar, salt,  beans, rice, bread, and plastics for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of sugar, salt, beans, rice, etc.

loans.name: Abahujimbaraga A Group

texts.fr:
Ndayambaje Theoneste, née à Ruhuha l’Est du Rwanda, il a 30 ans, il est marié et il a 3 enfants, son ainé a 8 ans et son cadet a 5 ans, son niveau d’étude est primaire. Il vit avec sa famille à Ruhuha Bugesera. 1 enfant va à l’école.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé ABAHUJUMUTIMA A cultivateurs de riz,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  agriculteurs de riz et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Theoneste et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en payant les minervals pour leurs enfants. Le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les engrais chimique pour felitiliser leur champ. Quand le groupe récolte, une partie de la récolte est vendue et une autre est utilisée pour la survie des familles des membres.
texts.en:
Théoneste Ndayambaje was born in Ruhuha, in Eastern Rwanda. He is 30 years old and married with three children. The eldest is 8 years old, and the youngest is 5. He attended primary school. He and his family live in Ruhuha-Bugesera. One of the children goes to school. He is a member of ABAHUJUMUTIMA A, a solidarity group of rice farmers who guarantee each other’s loans. Théoneste and his group work to support their families, to improve their living conditions, and to pay for the children’s tuition fees. The group took out a loan with Amasezerano Community Banking to buy the chemical fertilizers needed for their fields. After the harvest, part of the crop will be sold, and another portion will be used to support the members’ families.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy urea and N.P.K, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Nancy Muthoni

texts.en:
Nancy Muthoni is a hardworking lady of 43 years. She is married to John M., a mechanic, and together they have three children aged 22 years, 19 years and 16 years. Nancy has been farming for about five years and earns a monthly income of Kshs 20,000.

Having had no history with any other microfinance institution, when she learned about KADET she immediately applied for her first loan of Kshs 50,000. She intends to use the loan to buy a stock of poultry feeds and more poultry to keep so that she will have more eggs to sell to her customers. She plans to use the profits from the expanded business to start dairy farming which is also very profitable in her area.

Nancy hopes to grow her business and become the leading local investor and to see her children realizing their dreams in life through education.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of poultry feeds and more poultry to raise

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, flour, sugar, salt, gallons of palm oil, etc.

loans.name: Kyosimba Onanya Kibuga Group-Mpigi

texts.en: Fort-eight year old N. Gertrude belongs to Kyosimba group-Mpigi.  It is with persuasion from a close friend that she took up the gauntlet to start this clothes sales business. Her business has now lasted 15 years and she envisages even better prospects with the acquisition of this loan, as she will be able to resell more and make more profit. She was, prior to this, a hairdresser, and in a week, her profits equate to 550,000 shillings. With this loan this happy go lucky and amiable mother of 9 is anticipating going on a buying spree. With more clothes purchased she says she will be able to resell more.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Kayembe Development, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Operating a grocery and produce store has really improved T. Adrine's living conditions. In the past, T. Adrine, now 34, was involved in the farming business. Eighteen years ago, she changed her business into a food enterprise of products such as beans, millet flour, peas, and maize. She has been running this business from Rukungiri's central market, where she earns 280,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

As a married mother of 5 children, Adrine has been hardworking, knowing her responsibilities are cut out for her. She has been able to satisfy her family's requirements, including school fees for her children and other necessities, with help from her husband. Her drawback is having only a small stock of goods in her business. The loan she is requesting will enable her to expand the business through buying more goods and thus increasing her capacity to supply a ready market of customers. This will enable her to earn more sales revenue and live a more sustainable life as she looks at business expansion and building up a store.

loans.use: Purchase more stock

loans.name: Gladys Wanjiku

texts.en:
Gladys has been selling charcoal in Naivasha town for the last eight years. She is 29 years old, is married to Julius C., and they have two children.

Gladys was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan from them. She plans to buy ten sacks of charcoal to sell.

Gladys hopes to see her children through school and to build a house for her family in the future.

loans.use: To buy ten sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Ntara Multipurpose Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Enterprising and trustworthy T. Patrick of Ntara multi purpose group and aged 35, started up his hardware business over 2 years ago dealing in general building merchandise. Being strategically located in Ntara trading centre Ibanda, he gets many customers, earning him a profit of 400.000 Ugandan shillings monthly.  Patrick employs two casual labourers who help him with work in the shop, like lifting cement bags and iron bars. His main drawback is having small stock that cannot match the demand from the customers.

With this loan, he hopes to buy more stock of goods for the business, and this will help him expand business market and also earn more sales revenue to cater for the requirements of his family, educate his children, and also be able to progress economically.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for the business.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles L. is an older married man with for four children. His wife is a farmer in Bukura whereas he does welding services for the local people and schools around Bukura in Kakamega. Kakamega is in the western side of Kenya. It is well known as the sugar belt region for its large production of sugarcane. He has been in this business for the last four years. Charles says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is lack of staff and enough money to facilitate transportation of his products. However, he works very hard everyday to ensure that his business is doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 30,000 to buy a drilling machine. This will increase efficiency, therefore serving more customers. He hopes to open another metal shop in Kakamega. In the future, he hopes to open a college to educate young people about the kind of business that he does. He describes himself as very hardworking and determined.

loans.use: Drilling machine

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah A. is fifty six years old, married to a farmer and they have eight children whom they hope to give good education to the university level. His business is located in a busy local market in Kakamega. Kakamega is in the western side of Kenya. It is well known as the sugar belt for its large production of sugarcane. He has been selling timber to the local people for the last twenty years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is lack of a power saw machine. Transportation of timber is also hard but he works very hard everyday to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more timber to grow his business and meet customer demands. He hopes to open a workshop, own a power saw machine and a lorry to ease business operations in the future. He describes himself as very hardworking and determined.

loans.use: To buy supplies of timber

loans.name: Konooweka Zibba  Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
In business, one has to take both the rough and the smooth along the way as he or she operates. That is the chequered nature of doing business. To sail through these waters safe and sound, one has to draw up blue print contingency plans on how to succeed without letting these affect the business. 

At least over the last 5 years that is exactly what 38 year old N. Harriet, who belongs to Konooweka ziba Group, Lugazi has done. She has taken time by the forelock in making decisions that have impacted positively on her clothes sales business in Ziba-Lugazi. Her business has been gaining ground, albeit the main problem has manifested itself in the lack of enough capital to purchase more bales of clothes to resell and henceforth make more profit. Harriet is a strong willed woman with a fun loving disposition. She is a happily married mother of 5 kids who all attend good schools in and around Ziba. To take root in this business she was helped by a close friend who gave her not only financial support but also confidence building advice on how to run a business. Harriet had no previous business experience. In a week she says she makes profits that add up to 150,000 shillings, and with this loan she is looking at buying more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more supplies of fish

loans.name: Mkusima Ene

texts.en:
Mkusima has been practicing livestock farming for three years in Naivasha town.  She is 42 years old, married to Koira ole Seraya and they have three children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the cash to buy five sheep and 10 goats which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

Mkusino hopes to have a dairy farm in future to sell her milk products in large quantities.

loans.use: To buy five  sheep and 10 goats which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase goods from Cali such as, horns, starters, alternators, spark plugs, and vehicle accessories.

loans.name: Dzame

texts.en:
Dzame is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. Her husband contributes to the family’s basic needs with his earnings as a driver. She owns a house that has piped water but no electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

She has two businesses that she has been operating for the past five years. The first is a retail shop from which she  sells candy, soaps and tea leaves. With her other business she sells charcoal. Previously she cooked flat bread (chapati) and fried dough (maandazi) for sale. In addition she sells fresh water as another source of income. Dzame’s major challenge is seasonality. Her most difficult time of the year is the rainy season when the charcoal supply is low but the demand remains high. Thus she is unable to satisfy her customers' needs.  

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase thirty bags of charcoal to resell through her business. In the future, Dzame hopes to expand her business to include mobile phone charging services.

loans.use: To purchase thirty bags of charcoal.

loans.name: C2168 Amahoro Group

texts.en:
Madi is 40 years old and is married with two children: the first one is 10 years old and the last one is 8 years old.

Madi is a businessman who works hard so that he can provide all the basic needs of his family. He puts that hard work into a business he owns selling various styles of clothes. In particular, Madi is a new entrepreneur because he has an experience of only two years but he is well-known in his business and well-organized. The hours of his business are from seven in the morning to four in the evening, every day except Saturday.

Madi is the leader of this group of six members. He and his group are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their businesses. Through this expansion, all members of group will be able to satisfy their customers and can expect to earn more profits which will help them to save money and to sort out their family problems.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Killa Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “KILLA”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Wanchaq, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.


La socia es la Sra. Luisa; ella tiene 65 años de edad y es casada y tiene 6 Hijos; La socia  es propietaria de un restaurant turístico que queda ubicado en una de las calles de la ciudad de Cusco llamada Recoleta, ella trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 9:00 p.m ,ella prepara diferentes platos típicos de la ciudad de Cusco como chairo ( es como una sopa con verduras),rocoto relleno, lechón al horno ( chancho al horno) entre otro platos variados, la socia quiere mejorar el restaurant y ampliar.  La socia solicita el préstamo para implementar el restaurant para comprar utensilios para la cocina.


Los otros socios  se dedican la costureria, venta de ropa en el centro comercial, negocio de llamadas, restaurant.
La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members belong to the “KILLA” communal bank; This bank is located in the Wanchaq district, which is part of the Cusco province and department.


The member is Luisa; she is 65 years old and is married and has 6 children; the member owns a tourist restaurant which is located on one of the streets of the city of Cusco called Recoleta, she works from 8:00 a.m until 9:00 p.m, she prepares different dishes which are typical of the city of Cusco such as chairo ( it is a soup with vegetables), stuffed hot peppers, roasted suckling pig among other various dishes, the member wants to improve and expand the restaurant.  The member is requesting the loan to set up the restaurant by buying utensils for the kitchen.


The other members work as a seamstress, sell clothes in the commercial center, have a calling business, and a restaurant.
The member is grateful to whoever forms part of this dream through these means and promises to complete the payment installments in the established period.

loans.use: to set up the restaurant by buying utensils for the kitchen.

loans.name: Maria Estela

texts.es:
María de 42 años, tiene un centro medico, vive en una zona periurbana llamada “Duran” este lugar esta caracterizado por su ecología en disolución.  

Ella estudio enfermería y como vio la necesidad de un dispensario de salud comenzó a readecuar un lugar para atender a las personas de el sector donde vive. Trabaja todas las tarde atendiendo a las personas. Para obtener mas dinero ella y así solventar los gastos de la clínica de salud tiene una pequeña tienda que la atiende su hija. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar medicinas, productos para la tienda como enlatados, granos. En el futuro quiere tener ya un establecimiento medico bien construido y así ayudar a mas gente.
texts.en:
Maria is 42 years old and has a medical clinic. She lives in a zone called Duran on the fringe of the city, a location known for its deteriorating ecology. Maria studied nursing and, seeing the need for a health dispensary, she began to develop a place where she could attend to people from the sector where she lives. Maria works every afternoon, caring for clients. To obtain more money, and thus cover the costs of the health clinic, she has a small store that her daughter runs. With this loan Maria wants to buy medicines for her clinic and products for the store, such as canned goods and grains. In the future she wants to have an well-constructed medical establishment, in order to help more people.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING MEDICATIONS FOR HER CLINIC AND CANNED GOODS FOR THE STORE THAT SUPPORTS IT

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish at wholesale prices to sell to restaurants etc

loans.name: Paola Gisella

texts.es:
Paola de 21 años, tiene un negocio de mantenimiento de computadoras y diseño grafico. Vive en el suburbio de Guayaquil. 

Empezó con una computadora en su casa dando mantenimiento y haciendo diseños gráficos pero como tenia mucha clientela tubo que cambiarse de casa para poder readecuar el negocio. Poco a poco obtuvo mas clientela hasta ahora que ya tiene sus propias publicidades y con dos personas mas que le ayudan haciendo los diseños gráficos.

Quiere que su negocio sea uno de los mas conocidos por eso quiere comprar con el préstamo lectores de discos y impresoras para las publicidades. En el futuro quiere que su negocio sea uno de los mas conocidos locales de publicidad y ayudar a sus padres económicamente.
texts.en:
21-year old Paola runs a computer-repair and graphic design business. She lives in the suburb of Guayaquil. She started out with a computer in her house offering maintenance and doing graphic design. However, she had so many customers that she had to move house so she could have better premises for the business. Over time she got even more customers so that now she has her own advertising business and has hired two people to help with graphic design. Paola wants to see her business become one of the most well-known, so she is seeking a loan to buy CD players and printers for the advertising business. As well as her goal to see the business succeed, she wants to help her parents financially.

Translated from Spanish by Jane A, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy printers and CD players

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food. Her husband contributes to the family's basic needs through his earnings as a real estate agent.

For the last four years, Mariam has sold mitumba (secondhand clothes) from door-to-door. She faces the major challenge of delayed payments: many of her customers purchase clothes on credit and take a while to make payments. She hopes to open a retail shop in future.

Mariam decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase water pipes to start another business selling fresh water.

loans.use: To purchase water pipes to start a business selling fresh water

loans.name: Safina Group

texts.en:
Happiness J. is in her early thirties and is married with three children. For nine years, she has been operating a small cafe where she sells assorted drinks during the day and alcoholic beverages in the evening. The cafe is open daily between 9 a.m. and 11 p.m. and earns her a good monthly profit.

This will be Happiness's second Motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.

Happiness's first loan was used to buy new tables for her cafe, a loan which she has successfully repaid. She aims to use this second loan to buy new chairs for her cafe. Her dream is to one day build a new building for her business.

Happiness will share this loan with her loan group, Safina, which totals six members. The members of the group will hold each other responsible for repaying their loans.

In the photo, Happiness can be seen on the far right.

loans.use: To buy new chairs for her café

loans.name: C2888 Umurava Group

texts.en:
Martha has been a widow since 1955 and has two children. She is a businesswoman who has a business selling animals. This business is profitable and organized. Martha has an experience of five years in her business and the hours of her business are from six in the morning to six in the evening.

Martha is also group leader of this four member group, each member having her own business. She and her group are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their businesses through purchasing more products.

In Martha’s case that means buying more animals to sell and, with this expansion, she will be able to earn more profits which will be used for her family and in her business as well.

loans.use: To purchase more animals to sell

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.en:
Antoinette is 34 years old and has five children who range in age from 2 to 10 years.

Antoinette sells beer. She works with her husband and they have done this business for seven years. She is requesting a loan to buy a variety of beers for her bar in order to make more profits.

Antoinette’s dream is to have a wholesale store in the future where she hopes to sell many crates of beer and make more profits.

loans.use: To buy a variety of beers to sell

loans.name: Donatha

texts.en: Donatha is a hardworking mother with ten children that range in age from 3 to 32 years old.The eldest five children are married; hence, not in school, but the other children are in school. Her husband is a farmer. Donatha sells green bananas and banana juice. She has had this business for over 20 years. She is requesting a loan to buy more bananas in order to make more profits. She hopes to work hard and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy green bananas for sale

loans.name: Ernestine

texts.en: Ernestine is 40 years old. She has five children with ages that range from 1 month to 15 years. Her husband is a farmer. She has a shop in which she sells foodstuffs such as green bananas and other items such as salt, soap, juice and sodas. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more green bananas, salt, soap and soft drinks in order to make more profits. She has a clientele because of her good customer care and because her shop is the only shop in the neighborhood.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Finah

texts.en: Finah is 30 years old, married and has two children, ages 3 and 12. Her oldest child is enrolled in school. Her husband works in a garage. Finah sells fresh milk and, with the proceeds of this loan, she will buy more milk to sell. She says that her business is successful because she sells from a good location that attracts a lot of clients. Her business has allowed her to earn her own income and to sustain her family. With the profit from her business, she would like to open up a shop. She would also like to be able to buy a refrigerator so that she can store more liters of milk.

loans.use: To buy milk to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 48 years old. She is a widow and has four children between the ages of 14 and 25.  All of her children are enrolled in school.  She owns houses that she rents out and she also sells clothes.  She says that her clothing business is well known and clients can either come to her shop or she will deliver to them.  With the proceeds from this loan, Mary will purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Consolee

texts.en: Consolee is 36 years old, and she has twin seven-year-olds. They are both in primary school. Consolee has a women’s hair salon, and with the proceeds from this loan she will open up a men’s salon. She has recently moved to a new location and is building up her client base. With the profits from her business, she wants to improve the standard of living for her children.

loans.use: The opening of a men's salon

loans.name: Hadidja

texts.en:
Hadidja is 30 years old. She is married and she has one child, age 11, who is in school. Her husband is a driver.  

For the last four years, Hadja has been buying ladies’ and men’s clothes in Uganda and selling them in Rwanda. She will use this loan to buy more clothes. She plans to reinvest the profits back into her business and within a year, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

loans.use: Clothes to sell

loans.name: Josianne

texts.en:
Josianne is 29 years old and she is married with two children, ages 7 and 9. Both of her children are enrolled in school. Her husband works in a salon. 

Josianne sells fruit such as tree tomatoes, passion fruit and pineapples. She has had this business for three years. She says that her business is successful because it is very well-known and it is in a very strategic location.  

She will use the proceeds of this loan to buy more fruit to sell. With the profit from her loan, she hopes to open up a second location for her shop. In the future, Josianne hopes that she and her husband will be able to build a home for their family.

loans.use: Fruit to sell

loans.name: Speratha

texts.en:
Speratha is 38 years old. She is married and has five children between the ages of 3 and 13. All but her youngest child are enrolled in school. Her husband works with Urunana Company, an acting troupe that is hired to convey social messages through plays and other forms of entertainment.  

For the last five years, Speratha has had a shop where she sells things such as soap, alcohol, cooking oil and other food items. With the proceeds of this loan, she is going to make improvements to her shop.  She says that the success of her business is due to the good customer care that she provides.  With the profit from her business, she is going to save up for a piece of land.

loans.use: Improvements to the shop

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 27 years old. She is married and has two children, ages 7 and 3. Both of her children are enrolled in school. 

She sells food to teachers at a nearby nursery school. Soon, a hospital will be opening in the area, which will increase her number of clients. With this loan, she will buy more food to sell and she will also buy prepaid phone credit cards to sell as well.  

She says that her business has made her self-reliant and she no longer has to depend solely on her husband. She has even managed to buy a plot of land. With the profits from her business, she hopes to construct a house on her land.

loans.use: Food and prepaid phone credit cards to sell

loans.name: Ashula

texts.en:
